title: Amnesia
data:
**Amnesia** is an effect in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")* that causes the [player](/wiki/Player "Player") character to forget some of the knowledge they have accrued.

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Description](#Description)
- [2 Strategy](#Strategy)
- [3 History](#History)
- [4 Messages](#Messages)
- [5 Variants](#Variants)
  - [5.1 SLASH'EM](#SLASH.27EM)

## Description

A character afflicted by amnesia will potentially forget known [spells](/wiki/Spell "Spell"), dungeon level maps, [annotations](/wiki/Annotation "Annotation"), and even the [identities](/wiki/Identification "Identification") of items - entering a level whose map is forgotten due to amnesia will print a message. There are two sources of amnesia:

- a [read](/wiki/Read "Read") [scroll of amnesia](/wiki/Scroll_of_amnesia "Scroll of amnesia")
- an [intelligence](/wiki/Intelligence "Intelligence")-draining attack, specifically the tentacle attacks of [mind flayers](/wiki/Mind_flayer "Mind flayer") and [master mind flayers](/wiki/Master_mind_flayer "Master mind flayer")

Monsters will not read the scroll of amnesia, and brain-eating attacks only apply extra damage to other monsters.

*The following information pertains to an upcoming version ([NetHack 3.7.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.7.0 "NetHack 3.7.0")). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.*

Amnesia now forgets spells and skills; object identities and maps are not forgotten. Also, mind flayers no longer cause amnesia.

## Strategy

Amnesia is often a devastating occurrence for characters - not only is it one of many reasons why reading random [scrolls](/wiki/Scroll "Scroll") is a [Bad Idea](/wiki/Bad_Idea "Bad Idea"), but it is also one of the primary reasons behind the mind flayer's status as a gain-ruining menace. With this in mind, the best way to deal with amnesia is to avoid it as much as possible:

- Formally or informally identifying scrolls can detect a scroll of amnesia and make it easier to avoid.
- Mind flayers are enough of a threat with amnesia alone to warrant a [scroll of genocide](/wiki/Scroll_of_genocide "Scroll of genocide"), or even a blessed one if the character is not a [dwarf](/wiki/Dwarf_\(starting_race\) "Dwarf (starting race)") that would be wiped out by the scroll.
- Some especially paranoid players will [name](/wiki/Name "Name") one item out of each particular type that is considered vital and/or does not [auto-identify](/wiki/Auto-identify "Auto-identify") itself.

## History

Amnesia as a mechanic first appears in [Hack 1.0](/wiki/Hack_1.0 "Hack 1.0").

## Messages

- Thinking of [Maud](/wiki/Maud "Maud") you forget everything else.  
  Who was that Maud person anyway?

  You forgot the current level map along with other information due to reading a scroll of amnesia.

- As your mind turns inward on itself, you forget everything else.

  As above, but the character was named Maud.

- Your mind releases itself from mundane concerns.

  As above, while [hallucinating](/wiki/Hallucinating "Hallucinating").

* You have a sense of deja vu.

  You entered a level whose map you forgot.

*The following information pertains to an upcoming version ([NetHack 3.7.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.7.0 "NetHack 3.7.0")). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.*

The "deja vu" message is associated with [bones](/wiki/Bones "Bones") instead - adjust the message redirect so it points to that article.

## Variants

### SLASH'EM

[SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM") adds the [potion of amnesia](/wiki/Potion_of_amnesia "Potion of amnesia"), which causes amnesia when thrown or quaffed, and adds the [migo queen](/index.php?title=Migo_queen_\(SLASH%27EM\)\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Migo queen (SLASH'EM) (page does not exist)"), a monster with an intelligence-draining sting.

[![This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.](/images/f/f7/Nh367-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.")
